docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to win a six-month extension of protection from generic competition, the maker of OxyContin is renewing a clinical trial.

headline.seo: OxyContin’s Effect on Children in Testing by Purdue Pharma
headline.main: After Delay, OxyContin’s Use in Young Is Under Study
headline.print_headline: After Delay, OxyContin’s Use in Young Under Study

docs.abstract: Purdue Pharma, maker of the widely abused narcotic painkiller OxyContin, is renewing a clinical trial of the drug's use in children; Purdue is hoping to use the study to obtain a lucrative six-month extension of OxyContin's protection from generic competition, making use of a 1990s law that rewards drug makers for conducting clinical studies involving children.
docs.snippet: Hoping to win a six-month extension of protection from generic competition, the maker of OxyContin is renewing a clinical trial.

docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal to provide essential drugs free to hospital patients would fill a gap in health care at India’s state-owned hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.

headline.seo: India May Provide Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals
headline.main: India Weighs Providing Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals
headline.print_headline: India Weighs Providing Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals

docs.abstract: India is completing proposal to provide hundreds of essential drugs free to patients in government-run hospitals and clinics at a cost of nearly $5 billion over five years; proposal would fill a gap in health care at the hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.
docs.snippet: A proposal to provide essential drugs free to hospital patients would fill a gap in health care at India’s state-owned hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.

byline.contributor: Katie Thomas contributed reporting from New York.

docs.abstract: Young adults who question their time on psychotropic medications shouldn't scare parents away from treating a child who needs help.
docs.snippet: Young adults who question their time on psychotropic medications shouldn't scare parents away from treating a child who needs help.
